sub_topic: Finding the Ramsey number of a graph.
message_1: What is the Ramsey number R(3,4)?
message_2:
The Ramsey number R(m, n) is the smallest integer R such that any graph with R vertices will contain either a clique of size m (a complete subgraph with m vertices) or an independent set of size n (a set of n vertices with no edges between them).

For R(3,4), it is the smallest integer R such that any graph with R vertices will contain either a clique of size 3 (a triangle) or an independent set of size 4 (4 vertices with no edges between them).

The Ramsey number R(3,4) is 9. This means that in any graph with 9 vertices, there will always be either a triangle or an independent set of 4 vertices.
